title: 109_s1367
content: The Act aims to increase the number of highly accomplished recent college graduates teaching in underserved urban and rural communities, expand the reach of outstanding new teachers to more school districts, and develop a broader pipeline of talented leaders in public education and education reform. The Act authorizes a grant program for Teach For America to recruit, train, and support recent college graduates to teach in underserved communities for 2 years. The Secretary will enter into an agreement with the grantee to use funds for providing qualified teachers to high need local educational agencies, covering recruitment, training, and support of new teachers, and serving underserved students. Authorized activities include these provisions. Grant funds provided under this Act shall be used by the grantee for recruiting, training, and supporting teachers through a selective national process, rigorous summer institute, placement in high-need schools, and ongoing professional development for the first 2 years in the classroom. The grantee must use all funds to support activities related to the recruitment, selection, training, and support of teachers. SEC. 6. EVALUATION. The grantee must submit an annual report to the Secretary, including data on teachers provided, satisfaction of local educational agencies and principals, teacher background, training, placement sites, professional development, and retention. The Secretary will conduct a study on the achievement levels of students taught by teachers under this Act. The study mandated by the Act will compare the achievement gains of students taught by teachers assisted under the Act with those taught by teachers not assisted. The study must be conducted at least once every 3 years, include multiple placement sites and schools, and meet peer review standards. Authorization of appropriations for the Act includes necessary funds for fiscal year 2006 and up to $25,000,000 for each following fiscal year.
